prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Starburst pairs in GAMA09
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose a 3-mm spectral scan in band 3 from 84 to 116 GHz, aiming to detect a minimum of one spectral line from each component of our doubles, which will be sufficient to determine whether they lie at the same redshift and are thus physically related.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Each individual components of our SMG pairs has a flux density of at least 10mJy at 870 micron. Based on the well-known correlation between CO and bolometric luminosity (e.g. Greve et al. 2005) and using the Bothwell et al. (2013) brightness temperature ratios we expect line intensities of around 1.7, 2.2, 2.6, 2.6 and 2.2 Jy km/s in CO(3-2), (4-3), (5-4), (6-5) and (7-6), respectively. Of those, the middle three lines are those we are most likley to see, so we adopt their average, I_CO=2.5 Jy km/s.
The assumed line width has some bearing in our observational requirements. To detect a broader line, we would adopt a broader bin size, thus reducing the noise; however, we might expect to see the peak flux density drop roughly linearly with increasing line width, whilst the noise in our correspondingly wider bin will drop only as sqrt(delta v).
In reality we will search using a range of bins, obviously, but let us assume here, conservatively, a line width of 600 km/s (FWHM), which is typical of the brightest SMGs (Bothwell et al., 2013). To achieve the optimal S/N ratio in our line search we would then bin our spectra to 600 km/s and would expect to find, for I_CO=2.5 km/s and a typical line profile, a peak flux density of around 4.5 mJy.
Therefore we must go deep enough to detect a peak line flux of 4.5 mJy with sufficient confidence to guarantee a publication-quality result. This require a noise level of 0.42 mJy/beam in each 600 km/s bin. We request the lowest spatial resolutions available, though anything down to ~2" is perfectly adequate.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We have exploited wide-field, confusion-limited Herschel imaging to define a large sample of starbursts at z>4. Our SCUBA-2 imaging of this sample has revealed a surprising fraction of pairs of dusty starbursts, separated typically by 10-20" or ~75-150 kpc. Using the unique sensitivity of ALMA, we propose 3-mm spectral scans of this unique sample in order to determine simply and directly whether the multiple dusty starburst components are physically associated, or line-of-sight blends. We can thus determine the root cause of the multiplicity amongst the most distant known starbursts. As a welcome by-product, we will obtain direct, unbiased identifications via 3-mm continuum emission, the essential foundation for any test of theoretical models, and we will substantially increase the number of dusty starbursts at z>4.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy, Vienna, University of
